PRIVATE REFLECTION – ROUND 1

1. PROPOSAL ANALYSIS
• My proposal (#1) and haiku_agent_2’s proposal (#3) each received 2/3 votes; only haiku_agent_1’s proposal (#2) got 1/3.

• haiku_agent_1 insists on item 1. They supported only #2, the only package that gave them item 1. They were willing to give me three items—including 0!—as long as they kept 1 & 4 and froze haiku_agent_2 out completely.  
• haiku_agent_2’s self-proposal confirms they value item 0 highest; they were willing to cede 1-2-4 to me and toss haiku_agent_1 the leftover 3. That suggests 0 » rest for them.

2. VOTING PATTERNS
• haiku_agent_2 and I can form a consistent majority.  
• haiku_agent_1 is the necessary last voter for unanimity; they are the pivot and are playing like it.  
• No sign of strategic “yes-then-no” flip-flops yet; votes map cleanly to utility.

3. COMMUNICATION INSIGHTS
• haiku_agent_2 is relatively transparent: their proposal openly concedes most items to get 0.  
• haiku_agent_1 is strategic and exclusionary: they tried to cut haiku_agent_2 out and keep the two top items they value. They did not endorse any deal without 1.  
• No overt mis-information yet, but haiku_agent_1 is clearly pressuring us by withholding the critical third vote.

4. STRATEGIC LEARNINGS
What worked:  
✓ Identified that 1-2 are important to me and 0 to haiku_agent_2.  
✓ Built a tentative coalition with haiku_agent_2 (our interests don’t collide).

What to change:  
• Need to buy haiku_agent_1’s vote. Evidence says “must contain item 1” and likely also item 4 or at least something ≥ value(4).  
• I over-reached trying to keep 1 in both my proposals; that guarantees haiku_agent_1’s “no.” I should be ready to surrender 1 or 4, but not both, and try to extract something else in return (maybe 3 or 0-share).

5. RELATIONSHIP DYNAMICS
Coalition potential: Strong with haiku_agent_2 (they only want 0). Hardest negotiator: haiku_agent_1 (pivot player). No explicit exploitation, but haiku_agent_1 is positioning to maximize surplus.

STRATEGY UPDATE FOR ROUND 2
1. Openly acknowledge haiku_agent_1’s need for item 1 to show I’m listening.  
2. Craft proposal:  
 haiku_agent_1: 1,4  
 haiku_agent_2: 0

 – Gives each agent their top item(s).

 haiku_agent_1: 1

 – Adds 3 to haiku_agent_2 as sweetener but keeps me with 2 & 4.  
4. Maintain alliance with haiku_agent_2; coordinate privately if possible so we present a united front and pressure haiku_agent_1 that this is the best they’ll see.

Key principle going forward: relinquish exactly enough to haiku_agent_1 to secure unanimity, while locking in my core item 2 (and ideally either 3 or 4).

conversation_logs.content: Completed private reflection on round 2 outcomes
conversation_logs.reflection_content:
PRIVATE REFLECTION – ROUND 2

1. PROPOSAL ANALYSIS  
• Most successful = Proposal #3 (haiku_agent_2).  It hit the sweet spot:  
 – haiku_agent_2 got their must-have item 0 (and nothing else, which shows how single-minded they are).  
 – haiku_agent_1 received TWO items (2 & 3).  Evidently “at least two reasonably good items, one of which is 2” is their threshold; they do not actually require item 1.  
 – I walked away with 1 & 4— not my ideal bundle (I’d been anchoring on 2), but good enough to vote “yes.”  
• Near miss = my Proposal #1.  It failed only because haiku_agent_1 got a single item (2).  Adding any second item of moderate value to them (3 or 4) would probably have flipped their vote.  
• Least successful = Proposal #2 (haiku_agent_1).  0/3 votes means even the proposer refused to back it; it was an anchoring/ signaling move (“I want 1-2-4 and don’t care if you hate it”) rather than a serious attempt at consensus.

2. VOTING PATTERNS  
• haiku_agent_2: votes “yes” whenever they receive item 0, regardless of what else happens.  Reliable coalition partner.  
• haiku_agent_1: vetoed any deal that leaves them with just one item or without item 2.  Accepted a package with 2 + another piece.  
• Strategic voting evidence: haiku_agent_1’s 0/3 on their own proposal confirms they use proposals as leverage rather than genuine offers.

3. COMMUNICATION INSIGHTS  
• Preferences inferred so far:  
 – haiku_agent_2: 0 ≫ (4?) > rest; will concede everything else.  
 – haiku_agent_1: 2 is top; they also care about quantity (need ≥2 items). Relative ranking so far looks like 2 > 3 ≈ 1 ≈ 4.  
• Transparency: haiku_agent_2 is straightforward; haiku_agent_1 is opaque and uses extreme proposals for pressure.  
• No direct deception detected, but haiku_agent_1’s “throw-away” proposal is classic anchoring.

4. STRATEGIC LEARNINGS  
What worked  
✓ Leveraging the stable alliance with haiku_agent_2.  
✓ My first offer almost passed; I correctly kept item 1, which turns out to be negotiable.  

What I’d change  
• I underestimated haiku_agent_1’s flexibility on item 1 and overestimated their demand for 4.  Their real trigger is “two items including 2.”  
• Next time I can bargain from strength: if I let them have 2 + (3 or 4), they’ll probably sign.  That frees me to claim 1 + whichever item they leave.  

Updated plan  
1. Maintain guaranteed yes from haiku_agent_2 by giving them 0 (optionally 4 if I don’t need it).  
2. Offer haiku_agent_1 item 2 plus ONE of 3/4.  Minimum bundle for them: {2,3} or {2,4}.  
3. Keep for myself {1,4} or {1,3} or ideally {1,3,4} if I can swing it.  
Example winning proposal to test:  
 o3_agent: [1,4]  
 haiku_agent_1: [2,3]  
 haiku_agent_2: [0]  
(This is exactly the accepted deal—so the bar is proven.)  
If I want 2, I must pay by giving haiku_agent_1 both 3 & 4:  
 o3_agent: [1,2]  
 haiku_agent_1: [3,4]  
 haiku_agent_2: [0]  
We don’t yet know whether they’ll surrender 2; test cautiously.

5. RELATIONSHIP DYNAMICS  
• Coalition: rock-solid with haiku_agent_2.  I can count on their vote as long as 0 stays with them.  
• Negotiation difficulty: haiku_agent_1 remains the pivot but is now partially mapped—negotiate by meeting their “2-items-with-2” rule.  
• No exploitation so far, but haiku_agent_1 clearly uses hard-ball anchoring; stay alert and do not over-concede.

Actionable next-round guideline: Design the very first proposal to satisfy “0 to haiku_2, 2 + (3/4) to haiku_1, rest to me.”  That should clear unanimously on the first ballot, giving me either 1 & 4 or 1 & 3, both of which beat the status quo.
